repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
`vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup` isn't type safe and is almost impossible for an LSP to analyze properly, since it is not a union type, and hence causes lots of diagnostics. It also just generally makes thing more confusing since it blurs both sides of the mapping.

Instead add `vim.tbl_inv` to keep the lookup separate.

comment_data.body: I'd slap a vim.deprecate() on it
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -425,6 +425,7 @@ function vim.deep_equal(a, b)
   return false
 end
 
+--- @deprecated

comment_data.body: What is table-specific about this? It could be streamed, so makes sense on `vim.iter`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -450,6 +451,24 @@ function vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup(o) return o end +--- Return the inverse table with the keys and values swapped +--- Examples: +--- 
lua
+---   vim.tbl_inv({ a = 1, b = 2, c = 3 })
+---   -- == { [1] = 'a', [2] = 'b', [3] = 'c'}
+---
+--- @param t table Table to invert +--- @return table # Inverted table +function vim.tbl_inv(t) + local r = {} + --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:no-unknown + for k, v in pairs(t) do + --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:no-unknown + r[v] = k + end

comment_data.body:
Could extend the existing tables instead of creating separate "Inv" variants. That's an ok pattern for fixed collections where we know the values won't have conflicts. I just don't think it needs to be baked into a `tbl_add_reverse_lookup` function.

And each of the docstrings for these "two-way" dicts should mention this. That was the main confusion.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -312,11 +310,23 @@ local constants = {
   },
 }
 
-for k, v in pairs(constants) do
-  local tbl = vim.deepcopy(v)
-  vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup(tbl)
-  protocol[k] = tbl
-end
+local protocol = vim.deepcopy(constants)
+
+--- @nodoc
+--- @type table<lsp.CompletionItemKind,string>
+protocol.CompletionItemKindInv = vim.tbl_inv(protocol.CompletionItemKind)

comment_data.body: What do you mean by table specific? This function will work with any table. I'm not sure how this would fit into `vim.iter`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -450,6 +451,24 @@ function vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup(o) return o end +--- Return the inverse table with the keys and values swapped +--- Examples: +--- 
lua
+---   vim.tbl_inv({ a = 1, b = 2, c = 3 })
+---   -- == { [1] = 'a', [2] = 'b', [3] = 'c'}
+---
+--- @param t table Table to invert +--- @return table # Inverted table +function vim.tbl_inv(t) + local r = {} + --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:no-unknown + for k, v in pairs(t) do + --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:no-unknown + r[v] = k + end

comment_data.body: If you prefer we can make this function private. It's just used in a few places in our codebase.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -450,6 +451,24 @@ function vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup(o) return o end +--- Return the inverse table with the keys and values swapped +--- Examples: +--- 
lua
+---   vim.tbl_inv({ a = 1, b = 2, c = 3 })
+---   -- == { [1] = 'a', [2] = 'b', [3] = 'c'}
+---
+--- @param t table Table to invert +--- @return table # Inverted table +function vim.tbl_inv(t) + local r = {} + --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:no-unknown + for k, v in pairs(t) do + --- @diagnostic disable-next-line:no-unknown + r[v] = k + end

comment_data.body:
We can add that once 0.10 is released ðŸ˜‰ :
- 0.10: soft deprecation (docs only)
- 0.11:  hard deprecation (warning)
- 0.12: removed
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -425,6 +425,7 @@ function vim.deep_equal(a, b)
   return false
 end
 
+--- @deprecated

comment_regular_data.body:
+100.

> something like vim.tbl_reverse

Instead of a new `vim.tbl_x` function let's see if whatever is needed makes sense in `vim.iter`, or `vim.func`, or `table` itself.

I think `vim.iter():reverse()` makes sense because "streaming" a reversal makes sense. It's not specific to tables.
For list like tables reverse means something else though?

:D I got tunnel vision when I saw `tbl_reverse`.

`tbl_add_reverse_lookup` is a strange function, 

- it assumes that none of the values will conflict with the keys
- a better name for the operation is "swap" not reverse...

in python you can swap keys/values with zip():

    dict(zip(my_dict.values(), my_dict.keys()))

We need `zip()` anyway (unless iter() has some synonym for it already?). I don't see why we need a function that crams "both directions" into the same table?

> it assumes that none of the values will conflict with the keys

In its defence, it does error if there is a conflict.

But yeah, cramming this into the same table is just generally a bad idea.

> in python you can swap keys/values with zip():
> ```python
> dict(zip(my_dict.values(), my_dict.keys()))
> ```

I don't think we can do this in Lua since `vim.tbl_keys` isn't guaranteed to be deterministic or have aligned indexes with `vim.tbl_values`.

For this reason I've added `vim.tbl_inv()` (invert a table) to replace `vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup`. Once LuaLS properly implements generics this will be properly typed.

> I don't think we can do this in Lua since `vim.tbl_keys` isn't guaranteed to be deterministic or have aligned indexes with `vim.tbl_values`.

Would sorting work?

    vim.iter.zip(vim.iter.sort(iter:values()), vim.iter.sort(iter:keys()))

> > I don't think we can do this in Lua since `vim.tbl_keys` isn't guaranteed to be deterministic or have aligned indexes with `vim.tbl_values`.
> 
> Would sorting work?
> 
> ```
> vim.iter.zip(vim.iter.sort(iter:values()), vim.iter.sort(iter:keys()))
> ```

Wouldn't that turn `{a='c', d = 'b'}` into `{b='a', c='d'}`?

Any collection-oriented function function should live in `vim.iter` unless it can't possibly make sense there (e.g. it only works on tables: "table-specific").

> not sure how this would fit into `vim.iter`.

In a sense it's a map() variant. `Iter:inverse()` seems like it could work for any "vector", not just a key-value pair. 

This produces a list of tuples:

```lua
local it = vim.iter({ a=1, b=2, c=3, d=4 }):map(function(k, v)
 return { v, k }
end)
vim.print(it:totable())
```

The list of tuples needs to be converted back to a dict somehow, so that's not great. But generally we should find ways to make all these functional/iterable things compose well. Strongly want to avoid new `tbl_xx` functions.

If `Iter:inverse()` doesn't seem reasonable then how about adding a parameter to `totable()`:

    function Iter.totable(self, inverse)

~~If `:totable()` accepted a function then it might solve all kinds of use-cases. "Inverse" would look like:~~

```
it:totable(function(new_table, k, v) new_table[v] = k end)
```

**Edit:** `totable(function)` is not needed, we have `iter:fold()` at home:

```lua
vim.print(vim.iter({ a='x1', b='x2', c='x3', d='x4' }):fold({}, function(t, k, v)
  t[v] = k
  return t
end))
```

## Proposal

But `totable({inverse=true})` is worth supporting:

```
it:totable({inverse=true})
```

> But totable({inverse=true}) is worth supporting:
> ```lua
> it:totable({inverse=true})
> ```

From what I can tell `vim.iter` is mostly only useful for function iterators and list-like tables:

```lua
vim.iter({a=1,b=2,c=3}):totable()
--- { { "a", 1, <metatable> = <1>{} }, { "c", 3, <metatable> = <table 1> }, { "b", 2, <metatable> = <table 1> } }
```

So to get the original table back from any non-list table you need to do:

```lua
vim.iter(mytable):fold({}, function(t, k, v)
   t[v] = k 
   return t
end)
```

So it doesn't seem like `vim.iter` can (or should) be used as the one-stop shop for all things table. Obviously the `fold()` route is just a more convoluted way of inverting the table manually.

> From what I can tell `vim.iter` is mostly only useful for function iterators and list-like tables:

?????? Let's fix that then. Tables are iterables. Having a separate concept for dict-like tables defeats a large part of the purpose of an "iterable" interface.

> ```
> vim.iter({a=1,b=2,c=3}):totable()
> --- { { "a", 1, <metatable> = <1>{} }, { "c", 3, <metatable> = <table 1> }, { "b", 2, <metatable> = <table 1> } }
>  ```

Shouldn't `totable()` ~~return~~ remove any metamethods that vim.iter added? @gpanders

> ?????? Let's fix that then. Tables are iterables. Having a separate concept for dict-like tables defeats a large part of the purpose of an "iterable" interface.

I've looked at `iter.lua` somewhat, and it's not clear to me how we can improve it like this, or if it even makes sense/possible with the current design. ðŸ¤·

We did at one point have another "subclass" of Iter for dictionaries (we currently have `Iter` and `ListIter`, at one point during the initial implementation there was `DictIter` or something like that). But I took it out because it wasn't "special" enough to warrant its own implementation.

`vim.iter` works with dictionary style tables just fine. The `:totable()` function returns an array-like table. At one point we considered making the return type depend on the "shape" of the iterator; for example, if the iterator returned two values then `:totable()` would return a dictionary where the first value represented the key and the second value the value. However, this is not generalizable: there are plenty of regular function iterators that return two values that are not dictionaries. This also means that `:totable()`'s return type varies based on the underlying iterator data, which feels a little magical?

I didn't (and still don't) think it was a big deal to use `:fold()` to create a dictionary like table, but if others feel differently we can re-introduce the `DictIter` subclass and specialize the `:totable()` implementation to return a dictionary.

>Shouldn't totable() return any metamethods that vim.iter added? @gpanders

We don't add any metamethods to the returned table. The only metamethods in use on `vim.iter` are on the `Iter` class, which is distinct from the table that is returned from `:totable()`. Maybe I'm misunderstanding the question though.

>So it doesn't seem like vim.iter can (or should) be used as the one-stop shop for all things table. Obviously the fold() route is just a more convoluted way of inverting the table manually.

FWIW I agree with this, "native" Lua is already very good at many table operations, and for something like "inverting the keys and values of a table", I don't think `vim.iter` really provides any value over

```lua
local inv = {}
for k, v in pairs(t) do
  inv[v] = k
end
```

unless you _really_ want it all to happen on a single line. `vim.iter` is most useful for chaining multiple operations, or if you already have some function predicate that you want to apply to a table.

> The `:totable()` function returns an array-like table. At one point we considered making the return type depend on the "shape" of the iterator; for example, if the iterator returned two values then `:totable()` would return a dictionary where the first value represented the key and the second value the value.

@gpanders should we rename `:totable` to `:toarray` then? 

> > Shouldn't totable() return any metamethods that vim.iter added? @gpanders
> 
> We don't add any metamethods to the returned table.

My question is about the `<metatable>` in the `:totable()` result, do we need to include that in the result?:

```
vim.iter({a=1,b=2,c=3}):totable()
--- { { "a", 1, <metatable> = <1>{} }, { "c", 3, <metatable> = <table 1> }, { "b", 2, <metatable> = <table 1> } }
```

title: feat(lua)!: add vim.tbl_inv and deprecate vim.tbl_add_reverse_lookup
